title: 113_hr4699
content: The Act may be cited as the "Indian Country Economic Revitalization Act of 2014". It includes findings related to economic development in Indian Country. Congress finds the need to amend the Native American Business Development Act to expand Federal support for economic development of Indian tribes and lands, due to recent negative impacts from fiscal priorities. The Federal Government has a trust responsibility to Indian tribes and should support tribal-owned enterprises and Indian-owned businesses by recommending improved statutory measures to Congress for sustainable tribal economies, reducing their dependence on Federal funds. The Native American Business Development, Trade Promotion, and Tourism Act of 2000 is amended to include a new section on reporting and recommendations to Congress regarding tribal economic development. This aims to support tribal-owned enterprises and Indian-owned businesses for sustainable tribal economies. The Secretary of Commerce must report to Congress every 3 years on promoting economic growth for Indian tribes and lands, consulting with various federal agencies. The report, prepared by the Secretary of Commerce, the White House Council on Native American Affairs, and Indian tribes, includes data on Indian business development and employment over a 3-year period, with the first report covering a 10-year period. Data sources include decennial census information and data voluntarily provided by Indian tribes and businesses. The report, prepared by the Secretary of Commerce, the White House Council on Native American Affairs, and Indian tribes, includes data on Indian business development and employment over a 3-year period, with the first report covering a 10-year period. It assesses existing structural advantages and barriers to economic development on Indian lands, including the impact of federal judicial decisions and administrative actions on economic activities within Indian lands. The report includes an analysis of tax incentives, infrastructure access, educational opportunities, and investment capital for Indian economic development, with recommendations for Congress on legislation. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations to Congress on legislation to strengthen the economies of Indian tribes and lands, including regulatory, tax, and trust reform. The Secretary of Commerce will consider information from previous studies in conducting these studies. The curr_chunk discusses a report on developing tribal economies to create healthy, sustainable, and culturally vibrant communities, dated 2007. It also mentions another report titled "Growing Economies in Indian Country: Taking Stock of Progress and Partnerships", dated April 2012.
